title.english: Gingitsune: Messenger Fox of the Gods

description:
Gintaro is a fox spirit that has been protecting the small Inari temple since the Edo era. Saeki Makoto's family possesses the power to see the gods' agent, but the ability is limited to one living relative at a time. When Makoto's mother passed away while she was still young, Makoto inherited the ability as the sole remaining family member. With the help of fox spirit's power, Makoto and Gintaro help the people of their community, in spite of their many differences.

(Source: MangaHelpers; edited)

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/yamayama800) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/山口宏_(脚本家%29)

He's Japanese screenwriter and novelist, and one of the founders of Studio [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/GONZO).

A four-member Japanese pop band that formed in 2012 as an indie band. After releasing one album independently, they were signed in 2013 to Lantis. They released their debut single "Que Sera Sera" in August 2013. 

Fhána originally formed with [Junichi Satou](https://anilist.co/staff/127344), Yuxuki Waga and Kevin Mitsunaga, and all three had previously been involved in separate indie bands. Fhána did not have a fixed vocalist at first, instead employing guest vocalists to sing the band's songs. Fhána released their independent album New World Line on May 18, 2012 featuring four guest vocalists: Makiko Naka, Towana, IA, and Aoi Tada. In late 2012, Towana joined Fhána as the official vocalist. Fhána was signed to Lantis in 2013 and released their major debut single "Que Sera Sera" on August 21, 2013; the song is used as the ending theme to the 2013 anime series The Eccentric Family (Uchouten Kazoku).

SCREEN mode is a unit formed by sound producer Masatomo Ohta and voice actor Yuu Hayashi.

[Website](http://screenmode.net/)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/iyaiyaenn/)

She started working as animator for [Shin-Ei Douga](https://anilist.co/studio/247/ShinEi-Animation), where she later debuted as assistant episode director on [Yakyuukyou no Uta](https://anilist.co/anime/10554//) and [Ikkyuu-san](https://anilist.co/anime/4935/) before she became storyboarder and then episode director on the [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2471/Doraemon-1979/) television series. In 1982, when another former Shin-ei director, [Fukutomi Hiroshi](https://anilist.co/staff/105280/Hiroshi-Fukutomi), established [Animaru-Ya](https://anilist.co/studio/386/Animaruya) she was one of the founding members together with Sanada Yoshinobu and [Honda Toshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/129528/Toshiyuki--Honda). She stayed at Animaru-Ya, which is presently known as [Ekura Animaru](https://anilist.co/studio/6257/Ekura-Animal), until 2004 before leaving to work as freelancer.

(Source: aniDB)
In March 2010, she graduated from Tokyo Animation College.

Current president of [diomedéa](https://anilist.co/studio/51/diomeda) since 2006. Makoto Kohara was formerly an animator at [Shaft](https://anilist.co/studio/44/Shaft) and trained animators such as [Mai Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/103975/Mai-Ootsuka). He is still occasionally active as a director and animator.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/magicmagico) He joined Okayasu Promotion after graduating and studied there as editor, he collected experience on tv animation and drama and gave his debut on Ninja Hattori. He is currently working for 1000 Yamakoshi. Not to be confused with the other Toshihiko Kojima whose name is written with different Kanji.
